KID II Darius Miles, the 6-9, 18-year-old prodigy from East St. Louis High school (Ill.), will become the 14th player in the modern era to go directly from high school to the pros - and the 10th player since Kevin Garnett to skip college since 1995. Michael Jordan, who picked Miles to play with on his summer-camp team in Santa Barbara, Calif., said he would take Miles if he had the first pick. ''I finally saw it in the paper and my mom put it in the scrapbook,'' Miles said. His idols? ''Kevin Garnett and Chris Webber. I love those guys. I was a big Fab Five fan when I was a kid. Even when C. Webb called the timeout and lost the title, I still loved him,'' Miles was 12 years old when he watched the Michigan-North Carolina title game in 1993.
BULL MARKET Chicago has 6 picks among the first 34. Orlando owns the Nos. 5, 10 and 13 picks. The Clippers, have Nos. 3, 18 and 30.

THE BIG THREE It's not a great big-man draft but three centers have emerged as lottery picks. At 7 feet, Texas' Chris Mihm is more skilled than rugged and teams are concerned about his toughness. Polite, well-spoken, he did not wear two diamond-studded earrings to the news media availability session yesterday - as Florida's Mike Miller did. Doesn't matter if you grew up in South Dakota, like Miller, the more hip-hop you appear, the better your chance of going higher, Minnesota's 7-1 sophomore Joel Przybilla comes from the same Gopher lineage as Randy Breuer and Kevin McHale. lakovos (Jake) Tsadalidas is the strongest of them all at 7-2, 282. Rugged down low he is the rare draftee who can score with his back to the basket. Whoever drafts Tsakalidis may have to pay a portion or all of a $1 million buyout to AEK, his club team in Greece.

N.C.A.A. BAD BOYS In a draft littered with 6-foot-and-under point guards, Michigan's 6-6 freshman Jamal Crawford may be plucked before Michigan State's Mateen Cleaves. Crawford played only 17 games this season because the N.C.A.A. ruled that he accepted money from a Seattle businessman while in high school. He tried to make himself eligible for the draft last season, but his letter reached the N.B.A. offices after the early-entry deadline. Erick Barkley may not go until late in the first round. He, too, drew the ire of N.C.A.A. investigators this season. Przybilla was not exactly on his way to becoming a four-year letter-winner, either. He did not understand why Minnesota Coach Dan Monson, who was brought in to clean up the program after Clem Haskins, insisted he go to class.
